Bind Types

#define DB_BIND_RELATIVE   0x00001u
 Relative binding using memory offset.
 
#define DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE   0x00000u
 Absolute binding using memory address.
 
#define DB_BIND_LATE_BINDING   0x80000u
 
#define DB_BIND_MASK   (DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE | DB_BIND_RELATIVE | DB_BIND_LATE_BINDING)
 

Data Binding

Detailed Description

Data is stored and retrieved through rows.

A row is a set of temporary buffers for storing the contents of database fields. Each field in a row can be stored in one of three locations: a managed internal buffer, a local variable referenced by memory address, or a member of a data structure. A row variable is independent of any specific row in the database and can be re-used for many insert, fetch and update operations.

Macro Definition Documentation

◆ DB_FIELD_NULL

#define DB_FIELD_NULL   DB_LEN_CONST(-1)

Indicates that the field is NULL.

◆ DB_ARRAY_DIM

#define DB_ARRAY_DIM (   x)    (sizeof(x) / sizeof(x[0]))

Get the dimension of a static array.

The dimension is computed at compile-time, so this value can be used as a constant.

◆ DB_NTS

#define DB_NTS   DB_LEN_CONST(-3)

Treat field as a NULL-terminated string.

◆ DB_BLOB_CHSIZE

#define DB_BLOB_CHSIZE   DB_LEN_CONST(-4)

For internal use only.

◆ DB_AUTOFIELD

#define DB_AUTOFIELD   DB_LEN_CONST(-5)

Manage length automatically.

◆ DB_BIND_STRUCT_MEMBER

#define DB_BIND_STRUCT_MEMBER (   field_no,
  type,
  bind_struct,
  member 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_OFFSET(bind_struct, member), DB_BIND_SIZE(bind_struct, member), -1, DB_BIND_RELATIVE }

Bind to the offset of a member variable within a struct.

Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for relative binding.

◆ DB_BIND_VAR

#define DB_BIND_VAR (   field_no,
  type,
  var 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(&var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(NULL), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Bind to the address of a non-pointer data type.

Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for absolute binding.

◆ DB_BIND_STR

#define DB_BIND_STR (   field_no,
  type,
  var 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(NULL), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Bind to the address of a statically allocated array or string.

Size is determined by the compiler. Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for absolute binding.

◆ DB_BIND_PTR

#define DB_BIND_PTR (   field_no,
  type,
  var,
  size 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), size, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(NULL), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Bind to a dynamically allocated pointer with a specified size in bytes.

Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for absolute binding.

◆ DB_BIND_STRUCT_MEMBER_IND

#define DB_BIND_STRUCT_MEMBER_IND (   field_no,
  type,
  bind_struct,
  value,
  ind 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_OFFSET(bind_struct, value), DB_BIND_SIZE(bind_struct, value), DB_BIND_OFFSET(bind_struct, ind), DB_BIND_RELATIVE }

Bind to the offset of a member variable and its length indicator within a struct.

Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for relative binding.

◆ DB_BIND_VAR_IND

#define DB_BIND_VAR_IND (   field_no,
  type,
  var,
  ind 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(&var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(ind), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Bind to the address of a non-pointer data type and its length indicator.

Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for absolute binding.

◆ DB_BIND_STR_IND

#define DB_BIND_STR_IND (   field_no,
  type,
  var,
  ind 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(ind), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Bind to the address of a statically allocated array or string and its length indicator.

Size is determined by the compiler. Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for absolute binding.

◆ DB_BIND_PTR_IND

#define DB_BIND_PTR_IND (   field_no,
  type,
  var,
  size,
  ind 
)    { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), size, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(ind), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Bind to a dynamically allocated pointer with a specified size in bytes and its length indicator.

Use this macro to initialize a db_bind_t structure for absolute binding.

Function Documentation

◆ db_alloc_row()

db_row_t db_alloc_row ( const db_bind_t *  binds,
db_fieldno_t  nfields 
)

Allocate a row using absolute or relative bindings.

Parameters
bindsArray of bindings.
nfieldsNumber of fields in binds.
Returns
  • Row handle.
  • NULL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: number of fields being bound is 0, binding structure is not valid.
  • DB_EBINDSIZE Invalid bind size. Data type and size don't match.
See also
db_free_row,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_alloc_cursor_row()

db_row_t db_alloc_cursor_row ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Allocate a row of managed fields corresponding to the fields defined by a cursor.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • Row handle.
  • NULL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid cursor handle.
See also
db_free_row,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_free_row()

db_result_t db_free_row ( db_row_t  hrow)

Free a row object.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_get_field_size()

db_len_t db_get_field_size ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Count the number of bytes used by a particular field in a row.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • Size of field, in bytes.
  • DB_LEN_FAIL on failure.

This function reports the maximum number of bytes that can be used by the field data. This size is fixed when the field is bound to the row and does not change when data is set with db_set_field_data or fetched into the row with db_fetch.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid row handle or field number.
See also
db_get_field_len, db_set_field_len,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_get_field_type()

db_vartype_t db_get_field_type ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Obtain the variable type used by a particular field in a row.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • Field data type.
  • NULL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid input parameter.
See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field error. Invalid field number.

◆ db_get_field_len()

db_len_t db_get_field_len ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Obtain the length of a the data stored in a row field.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • Length of field, appropriate to field's data type.
  • DB_FIELD_NULL if the field is NULL.
  • DB_NTS if field is a NUL-terminated string.
  • DB_LEN_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid row handle or field number.

The meaning of the length depends on the field's variable type:

  • DB_VARTYPE_ANSISTR: Number of 8-bit characters.
  • DB_VARTYPE_UTF8STR: Number of 8-bit characters.
  • DB_VARTYPE_UTF16STR: Number of 16-bit characters.
  • DB_VARTYPE_UTF32STR: Number of 32-bit characters.
  • All other types: Number of bytes.

If a length indicator was bound to the field using db_bind_t::ind_ptr, its value will be returned by this function.

See also
db_get_field_size, db_set_field_len,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_set_field_len()

db_result_t db_set_field_len ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield,
db_len_t  len 
)

Set the length of a particular field in a row.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
lenNew length of the field, or one of the following special values:
  • DB_FIELD_NULL if the field is NULL.
  • DB_NTS if field is a NUL-terminated string.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field error. Invalid field number.

For some types, len is not the number of bytes in the field. See db_get_field_len for the meaning of length for each variable type.

If a length indicator was bound to the field using db_bind_t::ind_ptr, it will be set to len by this function.

See also
db_get_field_size, db_get_field_len,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_get_field_buffer()

void* db_get_field_buffer ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Obtain the buffer used by a particular field in a row.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • pointer to the buffer containing the field data.
  • NULL - indicating invalid parameter.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field error. Invalid field number.

This buffer can be modified directly. To get the size of this buffer in bytes, call db_get_field_size. To get the data type of this buffer, call db_get_field_type.

To update the length of the data in this buffer, call db_set_field_len.

See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_get_field_flags()

db_flags_t db_get_field_flags ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Obtain the flags for a row field.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • A bit field containing one or more of:
    • DB_NOT_NULL if the field cannot be NULL.
    • DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE if the field uses an absolute binding.
    • DB_BIND_RELATIVE if the field uses a relative binding.
  • DB_LEN_FAIL on failure.

◆ db_get_field_data()

db_len_t db_get_field_data ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield,
db_vartype_t  ctype,
void *  data,
db_len_t  size 
)

Copy the data stored in a particular field in a row to data, a pointer to a variable of the type specified by ctype.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
ctypeVariable type of the data buffer.
dataPointer to a buffer where the returned field is to be stored.
sizelength of data buffer in bytes.
Returns
  • Length of returned data.
  • DB_LEN_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field error. Invalid field number.

Unlike db_get_field_buffer, this function can convert data between compatible types.

The length returned by this function may be different from the length returned by db_get_field_len. For example, when converting a DB_VARTYPE_UTF8STR field to a DB_VARTYPE_UTF16STR data buffer, the length in data will be shorter if the string contains any multibyte code points. The length will also be shorter if the buffer size causes the data to be truncated.

See also
db_set_field_data,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_set_field_data()

db_result_t db_set_field_data ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield,
db_vartype_t  ctype,
const void *  data,
db_len_t  data_len 
)

Copy the data stored in data to a particular field in a row.

data is a pointer to a variable of the type specified by ctype.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
ctypeType of data in the data buffer.
dataPointer to data buffer from which to set the field.
data_lenLength of data as appropriate for the data type.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field error. Invalid field number.
  • DB_ECONVERT Incompatible types: conversion is not possible.
  • DB_EBINDSIZE Invalid bind size.

Unlike db_get_field_buffer, this function can convert data between compatible types.

For some types, data_len is not the number of bytes in the data buffer. See db_get_field_len for the meaning of length for each variable type. Note that data_len corresponds to ctype, whereas db_get_field_len corresponds to db_get_field_type.

See also
db_get_field_data,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_is_null()

int db_is_null ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Checks to see if the given field is null.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • (1) when the given field is null.
  • (0) when the given field contains data.
  • (-1) on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field identified by nfield does not exist.
See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_set_null()

db_result_t db_set_null ( db_row_t  hrow,
db_fieldno_t  nfield 
)

Set a field to null.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
nfieldField number.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid row handle.
  • DB_EFIELD Field identified by nfield does not exist.

To make a field not null, use db_set_field_data.

See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling.

◆ db_bind_field()

db_result_t db_bind_field ( db_row_t  hrow,
const db_bind_t *  bind 
)

Bind a field in a row to a variable.

Parameters
hrowRow handle.
bindAddress of variable bind structure.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: number of fields being bound is 0, binding structure is not valid, data type is not known and autosize is selected.
  • DB_EBINDSIZE Invalid bind size. Datatype and size dont match.

◆ db_unbind_field()

)

hrowRow handle.
fieldnoField number.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid row handle,
See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

  • DB_OK when successful.
